contentrichtext.text: {| border="1" bgcolor="#ffffff" cellpadding="5" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" width="250" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Deltoidal hexecontahedron |- |align=center colspan=2|[[Image:deltoidalhexecontahedron.jpg|240px|Deltoidal hexecontahedron]]<br>''Click on picture for large version''<br>''[[:image:deltoidalhexecontahedron.gif|spinning version]]'' |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Type||[[Catalan solid|Catalan]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Coxeter diagram||{{CDD|node_f1|5|node|3|node_f1}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Face polygon||[[kite (geometry)|kite]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||60 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||120 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||62 = 12 + 20 + 30 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Face configuration]]||V3.4.5.4 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[List_of_spherical_symmetry_groups|Symmetry group]]||[[Icosahedral symmetry|I<sub>h</sub>]], H<sub>3</sub>, [5,3], (*532) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Point_groups_in_three_dimensions#Rotation_groups|Rotation group]]||I, [5,3]<sup>+</sup>, (532) |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Dihedral angle]]||154Â° 7' 17" |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||convex, [[face-transitive]] |- |valign=top align=center|[[Image:Small rhombicosidodecahedron.png|120px]]<BR>[[rhombicosidodecahedron]]<BR>([[dual polyhedron]]) |align=center|[[Image:deltoidalhexecontahedron net.png|120px|{{PAGENAME}} net]]<BR>[[Net (polyhedron)|Net]] |} In [[geometry]], a '''deltoidal hexecontahedron''' (also sometimes called a ''trapezoidal hexecontahedron'', a ''strombic hexecontahedron'', or a ''tetragonal hexacontahedron'') is a [[catalan solid]] which looks a bit like either an overinflated [[dodecahedron]] or [[icosahedron]]. It is sometimes also called the trapezoidal hexecontahedron or strombic hexecontahedron. Its [[dual polyhedron]] is the [[rhombicosidodecahedron]]. The 60 faces are deltoids or [[kite (geometry)|kites]] (not [[trapezoid|trapezoidal]]). The short and long edges of each kite are in the ratio 1.00:1.54. It is the only [[Archimedean solid|Archimedean]] [[dual polyhedron|dual]] which does not have a [[Hamiltonian path]] among its vertices. == Related polyhedra and tilings == {{Icosahedral truncations}} This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of deltoidal polyhedra with face figure (V3.4.n.4), and continues as tilings of the [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic plane]]. These [[face-transitive]] figures have (*n32) reflectional [[Orbifold notation|symmetry]]. {{Expanded table}} ==See also== *[[Deltoidal icositetrahedron]] == References == * {{The Geometrical Foundation of Natural Structure (book)}} (Section 3-9) * ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, John H. Conway, Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ISBN 978-1-56881-220-5 [http://www.akpeters.com/product.asp?ProdCode=2205] (Chapter 21, Naming the Archimedean and Catalan polyhedra and tilings, page 286, tetragonal hexecontahedron) ==External links== * {{Mathworld2 | urlname= DeltoidalHexecontahedron| title=DeltoidalHexecontahedron and Hamiltonian path | urlname2 = CatalanSolid| title2 = Catalan solid}} * [http://polyhedra.org/poly/show/42/trapezoidal_hexecontahedron Deltoidal Hexecontahedron (Trapezoidal Hexecontrahedron)] -- Interactive Polyhedron Model * [http://www.ict.griffith.edu.au/anthony/kites/gallery/#Ball Example in real life] -- A ball almost 4 meters in diameter, from ripstop nylon, and inflated by the wind. It bounces around on the ground so that kids can play with it at kite festivals. {{Polyhedron navigator}} {{Polyhedron-stub}} [[Category:Catalan solids]]
